title: 3  Algebra

3.5 The binominal theorem

Reference: Hass, Heil, and Weir (2018) and Khan Academy (n.d.) and Matika (n.d.)

For any positive integer \(n\),
\[
(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + na^{n - 1}b + \cfrac{n (n - 1)}{1 \cdot 2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \cfrac{n (n - 1) (n - 2)}{1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3}a^{n - 3}b^{3} + \cdots + nab^{n - 1} + b^{n}
\]
The same formula above can be written as (Newton’s binomial)
\[
(a + b)^{n} = \sum_{k = 0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} \cdot a^{n - k} \cdot b^{k} \quad , \quad \binom{n}{k} = \cfrac{n!}{k! (n - k)!}
\]
In the case of \((a - b)\):
\[
(a - b)^{n} = \sum_{k = 0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} \cdot a^{n - k} \cdot (- b)^{k}
\]
Note that when the power of \(− b\) is even, the product is positive and if the power is odd, the product is negative. Example:
\[
(a - b)^4 = a^{4} - 4a^{3}b + 6a^{2}b^{2} - 4ab^{3} + b^{4}
\]
See the “special products” section for more examples.

title: 9  Limits
text:
9.3 General laws

Reference: Hass, Heil, and Weir (2018)

If \(L\), \(M\), \(c\), and \(k\) are real numbers and
\(\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x) = L\) and \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} g(x) = M\), then

Sum rule: \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} [f(x) + g(x)] = L + M = \lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x) + \lim \limits_{x \to c} g(x)\)
Example: \(\lim \limits_{x \to 1} [x^{2} + 3x^{3}] = \lim \limits_{x \to 1} x^{2} + \lim \limits_{x \to 1} 3x^{3} = 1 + 3 = 4\)
Difference rule: \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} [f(x) - g(x)] = L - M = \lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x) - \lim \limits_{x \to c} g(x)\)
Product rule: \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} [f(x) \times g(x)] = L \times M = \lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x) \times \lim \limits_{x \to c} g(x)\)
Constant multiple rule: \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} (k \times f(x)) = k \times L = k \times \lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x)\)
Quotient rule: \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} \cfrac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \cfrac{L}{M} = \cfrac{\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x)}{\lim \limits_{x \to c} g(x)}\), \(M \neq 0\), \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} g(x) \neq 0\)

title: 9  Limits
text:
9.4 Infinite limit of rational functions

Reference: Hase (2022)

\[\lim \limits_{x \pm \infty} \cfrac{P_{n}(x)}{Q_{m}(x)} = \lim \limits_{x \pm \infty} \cfrac{a_{n}x^{n} + a_{n - 1}x^{n - 1} \cdots + a_{1}x + a_{0}}{b_{m}x^{m} + b_{m - 1}x^{m - 1} \cdots + b_{1}x + b_{0}} = \lim \limits_{x \pm \infty} \cfrac{x^{n} (a_{n} + \frac{a_{n - 1}}{x} \cdots + \frac{a_{1}}{x^{n - 1}} + \frac{a_{0}}{x^{n}})}{x^{m} (b_{m} + \frac{b_{m - 1}}{x} \cdots + \frac{b_{1}}{x^{m - 1}} + \frac{b_{0}}{x^{m}})}\]

\(n = m\): in this case, the largest term of the numerator (\(a_{n}x^{n}\)) is of the same order of magnitude with the largest term of the denominator (\(b_{m}x^{m} = b_{n}x^{n}\)), and the limit converges to \(\cfrac{a_{n}}{b_n}\).
\(n < m\): n this case, the denominator is much larger than the numerator, and the limit converges to zero.
\(n > m\): in this case, one should analyze the sign of the dominant term of the limit, which is \(\cfrac{a_{n}}{b_m} x^{n - m}\). If \(\cfrac{a_{n}}{b_m} x^{n - m} > 0\) when \(x \to \pm \infty\), then \(\lim \limits_{x \pm \infty} \cfrac{P_{n}(x)}{Q_{m}(x)} \to \infty\). On the other hand, if \(\cfrac{a_{n}}{b_m} x^{n - m} < 0\), when \(x \to \pm \infty\), then \(\lim \limits_{x \pm \infty} \cfrac{P_{n}(x)}{Q_{m}(x)} \to - \infty\)

title: 9  Limits
text:
9.5 Squeeze theorem (or sandwich theorem)

Reference: Hase (2022)

For an interval \(I \subset \mathbb{R}\), assume that \(g(x) \leq f(x) \leq h(x)\) with \(x \in I\). Given \(x_{0} \in I\), if
\[\lim \limits_{x \to x_{0}} g(x) = \lim \limits_{x \to x_{0}} h(x) = L \ \text{, then} \ \lim \limits_{x \to x_{0}} f(x) = L\].

title: 9  Limits
text:
9.6 The fundamental limit

Reference: Hase (2022)


Denote by \(S_{\triangle OPQ}\), \(S_{\triangle OPR}\), and \(S_{\sector OPQ}\), respectively, the areas of the triangles \(OPQ\), \(OPR\) and the circular section \(OPQ\), as in figure 4. Let \(r\) be the radius of the disk. It is straightforward that
\[S_{\triangle OPQ} \leq S_{\sector OPQ} \leq S_{\triangle OPR}\]
Since \(S_{\triangle OPQ} = \cfrac{r^{2} \sin x}{2}\), \(S_{\sector OPQ} = \cfrac{r^{2} x}{2}\), and \(S_{\triangle OPR} = \cfrac{r^{2} \tan x}{2}\), the above inequality implies
\[\sin x \leq x \leq \tan x \ \ \ \ \ \text{or} \ \ \ \ \ \cos x \leq \cfrac{\sin x}{x} \leq 1\]
Therefore, since \(\lim \limits_{x \to 0} \cos x = 1\) from the squeeze theorem, it follows that
\[\lim \limits_{x \to 0} \cfrac{\sin x}{x} = 1\]
One should be aware that this fundamental limit is valid when the angle \(x\) is measured in radians. If \(x\) is measured in degree, one would have \(S_{\sector OPQ} = \cfrac{r^{2} x}{2} \cfrac{\pi}{180}\), which would have lead to \(\lim \limits_{x \to 0} \cfrac{\sin x}{x} = \cfrac{\pi}{180}\).

title: 9  Limits

9.9 The l’Hôpital’s rule

Reference: Hase (2022)

Theorem: Let \(f\) and \(g\) be two differentiable functions on an open interval \(I\) and let \(\lim \limits_{x \to a} f(x) = \lim \limits_{x \to a} g(x) = \pm \infty\) or \(0\) (here, \(a \in \mathbb{R} \cup \{+ \infty, -\infty\}\), and \(f\) and \(g\) need not be defined on \(a\)). Furthermore, if \(g′(x) \ne 0\) at \(I ∖ \{a\}\) and \(\lim \limits_{x \to a} \cfrac{f′(x)}{g′(x)}\) exists, then
\[\lim \limits_{x \to a} \cfrac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \lim \limits_{x \to a} \cfrac{f′(x)}{g′(x)}\]

title: 10  Derivatives
text:
Reference: Hase (2022)
The derivative of function \(f\) at a point \(x\) is defined as
\[\cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} x} f(x) := \lim \limits_{\Delta x \to 0} \cfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \lim \limits_{\Delta x \to 0} \cfrac{f(x + \Delta x) - f(x)}{\Delta x}\]
A function is said to be differentiable if the derivative exists at every point of its domain. Here, the notation \(f'(x)\) is also used to indicate de derivative of \(f\) (at point \(x\)).
Note that, from a geometrical standpoint, the derivative at \(x\) corresponds to the tangent of the curve \(f\) at the same point. Therefore,
\[
\cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} x} f(x) =
\begin{cases}
    > 0 \ \ \ , \ \ \ \text{function } f \text{ increasing with } x \text{ (at } x \text{)}
\\
    < 0 \ \ \ , \ \ \ \text{function } f \text{ decreasing with } x \text{ (at } x \text{)}
\end{cases}
.
\]
The case \(\cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} x} f(x) = 0\) is especially important since it’s a necessary (although not sufficient) condition to determine the extremal points (local maxima and minima) of differentiable functions.

Product: \((fg)' = f' g + f g'\)

\([\sin(2x)]'\)

title: 13  Integrals
text:
Reference: Hase (2022)

The derivative \(f'\) of a function \(f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}\) is defined by the formula
\[
f'(x) = \lim \limits_{\Delta x \to 0} = \cfrac{f(x + \Delta x) - f(x)}{\Delta x}
\]
Now, a different question can be proposed: given \(f\), one may be interested in a function \(F\) such that
\[
F'(x) = f(x)
\]
for all \(x\) in the domain of \(f\). This is an inverse problem of derivation, and \(F\) is called an antiderivative of \(f\). One may immediately note that the antiderivative of a function is not unique; for instance, if \(f(x) = x\), then \(\cfrac{x^{2}}{2}\), \(\cfrac{x^{2}}{2} − 1\) and \(\cfrac{x^{2}}{2} + \pi\) are some possible antiderivatives. However, as these examples indicate, the difference between any two antiderivatives of a given function is a constant. This means that if \(F\) is an antiderivative of \(f\), any other antiderivative of \(f\) can be expressed by \(F + c\), where \(c \in \mathbb{R}\) is a constant.
If \(F(x)\) is an antiderivative of \(f(x)\) for \(x \in (a, b) \subset \mathbb{R}\), the family of functions \(\{F + c\}\), where \(c \in \mathbb{R}\) is a constant, is the indefinite integral of \(f\), and is denoted by
\[
\int f(x) \ dx
\]
id est,
\[
\int f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = F(x) + c, \quad c \in \mathbb{R}, \quad \text{if} \quad F'(x) = f(x)
\]
In \(\displaystyle \int f(x) \ dx\), \(f(x)\) is the integrand and the symbol \(dx\) (the measure of integration) will play an important role later. Some remarks:

From the definition, \(\displaystyle \cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} x} \int f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = f(x)\).
Geometrically, an indefinite integral is a family of curves, each one of them being related to others by a “vertical” translation.
Not every function has an indefinite integral; furthermore, not every function has an indefinite integral that can be expressed by a finite combination of elementary functions.

Indefinite integrals are also defined for linear combinations of functions. As a consequence of linearity in derivatives, the following linear properties hold:

\(\displaystyle \int [f(x) + f(x)] \ \mathrm{d} x = \int f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x + \int g(x) \ \mathrm{d} x\)
\(\displaystyle \int \alpha f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = \alpha \int f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x \quad (\alpha \in \mathbb{R})\)

To see the properties above, one should derive both sides of each identity and see that the results match. The identities should be understood in the sense that indefinite integrals are equivalent up to a constant. In particular, it follows that
\[
0 \cdot \int f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = \int 0 \cdot f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = \int 0 \ \mathrm{d} x = c \quad (c \in \mathbb{R})
\]
and
\[
\int f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x - \int f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = \int [f(x) - f(x)] \ \mathrm{d} x = \int 0 \ \mathrm{d} x = c \quad (c \in \mathbb{R})
\]
These two examples remind one that indefinite integrals are a family of functions, and not simple functions.

title: 13  Integrals
text:
13.2 Integral definida
Seja \(f(x)\) uma função e \(g(x)\) uma de suas primitivas. Portanto, \(\int f(x) \ dx = g(x) + c\) .
Definimos a integral definida de \(f(x)\) entre os limites \(a\) e \(b\) como a diferença \(g(b) - g(a)\), e indicamos simbólicamente \(\int_{a}^{b} f(x) \ dx = g(b) - g(a) = \lim \limits_{x \to b-} [g(x)] - \lim \limits_{x \to a+} [g(x)]\).
A diferença \(g(b) - g(a)\) também costuma ser indicada pelo símbolo \([g(x)]_{a}^{b}\).

13.2.1 Fundamental theorem of calculus
O significado geométrico da integral definida é dado a seguir.
Seja \(f(x)\) uma função contínua e não negativa definida num intervalo \([a, b]\). A integral definida \(\int_{a}^{b} f(x) \ dx\) representa a área da região compreendida entre o gráfico de \(f(x)\), o eixo \(x\) e as verticais que passam por \(a\) e \(b\).

Assim, indicado por \(A\) a área destacada da Figura 7.1, teremos: \(A = \int_{a}^{b} f(x) \ dx\).
(…) Caso \(f(x)\) seja negativa no intervalo \([a, b]\) , a área \(A\) da região delimitada pelo gráfico de \(f(x)\), eixo \(x\), e pelas verticais que passam por \(a\) e por \(b\) é dada por: \(A = - \int_{a}^{b} f(x) \ dx\).


13.2.2 Propriedades operatórias

\(\int \limits_{a}^{a} f(x) \ dx = F(a) - F(a) = 0\)
\(\int \limits_{a}^{b} f(x) \ dx = - \int_{b}^{a} f(x) \ dx\)
\(\int \limits_{a}^{b} f(x) \ dx = \int_{a}^{c} f(x) \ dx + \int_{c}^{b} f(x) \ dx\), sendo \(a < c < b\).

title: 13  Integrals
text:
13.3 Improper integral
Quando as hipóteses do teorema fundamental do cálculo falharem, aplicamos a integral imprópria.
Caso 1: Intervalo de integração aberto (e.g., \(]a, b]\)).
Caso 2: Descontinuidade da função (e.g., \(D = \mathbb{R} - (0)\)).
Usa-se a propriedade da integral definida: \(\int_{a}^{b} f(x) \ dx = \int_{a}^{c} f(x) \ dx + \int_{c}^{b} f(x) \ dx\) , sendo \(a < c < b\).
Exemplo:
\(\int \limits_{-1}^{1} \frac {1}{x^2} \ dx \ \longrightarrow \ D = \mathbb{R} - (0)\)
\(\int \limits_{-1}^{1} \frac {1}{x^2} \ dx = \lim \limits_{z \to 0^{-}} \int_{-1}^{z} \frac {1}{x^2} \ dx + \lim \limits_{z \to 0^{+}} \int_{z}^{1} \frac {1}{x^2} \ dx\)

3.5 The binominal theorem (Newton’s binomial)

Reference: Hass, Heil, and Weir (2018) and Khan Academy (n.d.) and Matika (n.d.)

For any positive integer \(n\),
\[
(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + na^{n - 1}b + \cfrac{n (n - 1)}{1 \cdot 2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \cfrac{n (n - 1) (n - 2)}{1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3}a^{n - 3}b^{3} + \cdots + nab^{n - 1} + b^{n}
\]
The same formula above can be written as
\[
(a + b)^{n} = \sum_{k = 0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} \cdot a^{n - k} \cdot b^{k} \quad , \quad \binom{n}{k} = \cfrac{n!}{k! (n - k)!}
\]

Example:

\[
(a + b)^4 = a^{4} + 4a^{3}b + 6a^{2}b^{2} + 4ab^{3} + b^{4}
\]
In the case of \((a - b)\),
\[
(a - b)^{n} = \sum_{k = 0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} \cdot a^{n - k} \cdot (- b)^{k}
\]
Note that when the power of \(− b\) is even, the product is positive and if the power is odd, the product is negative.

Example:

\[
(a - b)^4 = a^{4} - 4a^{3}b + 6a^{2}b^{2} - 4ab^{3} + b^{4}

Series with nonnegative terms: Try the Integral Test, Ratio Test, or Root Test. Try comparing to a known series with the Comparison Test or the Limit Comparison Test.
Series with some negative terms: Does \(\sum | a_{n} |\) converge? If yes, so does \(\sum a_{ n}\) because absolute convergence implies convergence.
Alternating series: \(\sum a_{n}\) converges if the series satisﬁes the conditions of the Alternating Series Test.

title: 12  Series
text:
12.2 Taylor series

Reference: Hase (2022)

Let \(f\) be a function that has all the “required” derivatives. One can demand its behavior in the neighborhood of a point, \(x_{0}\). In this case, it is possible to approximate \(f\) with a polynomial (around \(x_{0}\)), which is the Taylor series. Concretely, one has
\[
f(x) = a_{0} + a_{1}(x - x_{0}) + a_{2}(x - x_{0})^{2} + a_{3}(x - x_{0})^{3} + \cdots + a_{n}(x - x_{0})^{n} + \cdots
\tag{1}
\]
which is a polynomial representation in \((x - x_{0})\). Note that, intuitively, if the distance between \(x\) and \(x_{0}\) becomes small, the terms of this series decrease, a priori, with \(n\). The goal of this section is the determination of the set of coefficients \(\{a_{n}\}\).

Show, by imposing \(x = x_{0}\) in \((1)\), that \(a_{0} = f(x_{0})\).
Determine \(f′(x)\). Show, by imposing \(x = x_{0}\) in the resultant equation, that \(a_{1} = \cfrac{1}{1!} f′(x_{0})\).

Denote by \(\cfrac{d^{2}}{dx^{2}} f(x)\), or \(f′′(x)\), or \(f^{(2)}(x)\), the second order derivative of \(f\). This symbol stands for
\[
\cfrac{d^{2}}{dx^{2}} f(x) = \cfrac{d}{dx} \left [ \cfrac{d}{dx} f(x) \right ]
\tag{2}
\]
Exemplifying, if \(g(x) = \sin x\), then \(g′(x) = \cos x\) and \(g′′(x) = − \sin x\). Analogously,
\[
\cfrac{d^{3}}{dx^{3}} f(x) = \cfrac{d}{dx} \left [ \cfrac{d^{2}}{dx^{2}} f(x) \right ] = \cfrac{d}{dx} \left [ \cfrac{d}{dx} \left [ \cfrac{d}{dx} f(x) \right ] \right ] \quad , \quad \cfrac{d^{4}}{dx^{4}} f(x) = \cfrac{d}{dx} \left [ \cfrac{d^{3}}{dx^{3}} f(x) \right ] \cdots, \quad et \ cætera
\tag{3}
\]
Furthermore, for \(g(x) = \sin x\), one has \(g^{(3)} (x) = − \cos x\), \(g^{(4)} (x) = \sin x\), et cætera.

Determine \(f′′(x)\). Show, by imposing \(x = x_{0}\) in the resultant equation, that \(a_{2} = \cfrac{1}{2!} f′′(x_{0})\).
Determine \(f^{(3)} (x)\). Show, by imposing \(x = x_{0}\) in the resultant equation, that \(a_{3} = \cfrac{1}{3!} f^{(3)} (x_{0})\).
Show that \(a_{n} = \cfrac{1}{n!} f^{(n)} (x_{0})\).

In other words, if the series exists, one has
\[
f(x) = \sum \limits^{\infty}_{n = 0} \cfrac{1}{n!} f^{(n)} (x_{0}) (x - x_{0})^{n}
\]

12.4 Binomial series

Reference: Hass, Heil, and Weir (2018)

\[
(1 + x)^{m} =
1 + mx + \cfrac{m (m - 1) x^{2}}{2!} + \cfrac{m (m - 1) (m - 2) x^{3}}{3!} +
\cdots +
\]
\[

title: 12  Series
text:
12.3 Maclaurin series

Reference: Hass, Heil, and Weir (2018)

A Maclaurin series is a Taylor series where \(x_{0} = 0\).

\(\cfrac{1}{1 - x} = 1 + x + x^2 + \cdots + x^{n} + \cdots = \sum \limits^{\infty}_{n = 0} x^{n}, \quad |x| < 1\)
\(\cfrac{1}{1 + x} = 1 - x + x^2 - \cdots + (- x^{n}) + \cdots = \sum \limits^{\infty}_{n = 0} (-1)^{n} x^{n}, \quad |x| < 1\)
\(e^{x} = 1 + x + \cfrac{x^{2}}{2!} + \cdots + \cfrac{x^{n}}{n!} + \cdots = \sum \limits^{\infty}_{n = 0} \cfrac{x^{n}}{n!}, \quad |x| < \infty\)
\(\sin x = x - \cfrac{x^{3}}{3!} + \cfrac{x^{5}}{5!} - \cdots + (-1)^{n} \cfrac{x^{2n + 1}}{(2n +1)!} + \cdots = \sum \limits^{\infty}_{n = 0} \cfrac{(-1)^{n} x^{2n + 1}}{(2n +1)!}, \quad |x| < \infty\)
\(\cos x = 1 - \cfrac{x^{2}}{2!} + \cfrac{x^{4}}{4!} - \cdots + (-1)^{n} \cfrac{x^{2n}}{(2n)!} + \cdots = \sum \limits^{\infty}_{n = 0} \cfrac{(-1)^{n} x^{2n}}{(2n)!}, \quad |x| < \infty\)
\(\ln (1 + x) = x - \cfrac{x^{2}}{2} + \cfrac{x^{3}}{3} - \cdots + (-1)^{n - 1} \cfrac{x^{n}}{n} + \cdots = \sum \limits^{\infty}_{n = 1} \cfrac{(-1)^{n - 1} x^{n}}{n}, \quad -1 < x \leq 1\)
\(\ln \cfrac{1 + x}{1 - x} = 2 \tanh^{-1} x = 2 \left ( x + \cfrac{x^{3}}{3} + \cfrac{x^{5}}{5} + \cdots + \cfrac{x^{2n + 1}}{2n + 1} + \cdots \right ) = 2 \sum \limits_{n = 0}^{\infty} \cfrac{x^{2n + 1}}{2n - 1}, \quad |x| < 1\)
\(\tan^{-1} x = x - \cfrac{x^{3}}{3} + \cfrac{x^{5}}{5} - \cdots + (- 1)^{n} \cfrac{x^{2n + 1}}{2n + 1} + \cdots = \sum \limits^{\infty}_{n = 0} \cfrac{(- 1)^{n} x^{2n + 1}}{2n + 1}, \quad |x| \leq 1\)

title: 12  Series
text:
12.5 Big “Oh” notation

Reference: Hase (2022)

For \(x \ll 1\), expanding \(f(x) = \sin x\) aroung \(x_{0}\) leads to
\[
\sin x = x - \cfrac{x^{3}}{3!} + \cfrac{x^{5}}{5!} - \cfrac{x^{7}}{7!} + \cdots
\]
The term in the series above decreases with its order. The series can also be represented by
\[
\sin x = x - \cfrac{x^{3}}{3!} + \cfrac{x^{5}}{5!} - \cfrac{x^{7}}{7!} + \mathcal{O} (x^{9})
\]
where \(\mathcal{O} (x^{9})\) stands for contributions of order \(x^{9}\) (id est, proportional to \(x^{6}\)) or less, since the absolute value of the remaining terms \(\left | \cfrac{x^{9}}{9!} - \cfrac{x^{11}}{11!} + \cfrac{x^{13}}{13!} - \cdots \right |\), does not exceed a term proportional to \(x^{9}\). It was also possible to write
\[
\sin x = x - \cfrac{x^{3}}{3!} + \cfrac{x^{5}}{5!} - \cfrac{x^{7}}{7!} + \mathcal{O} (x^{8})
\]
because \(\mathcal{O} (x^{9})\) is (much) smaller than terms proportional to \(x^{8}\) when \(x \sim 0\).




Hase, Masayuki Oka. 2022. “Métodos Matemáticos e de Computação 1.”


Hass, Joel, Christopher Heil, and Maurice D. Weir. 2018. Thomas’ Calculus. 14th ed. Pearson.

title: 14  The n-dimensional space (\(\mathbb{R}^{n}\))
text:
14.2 Partial derivatives

Reference: Hase (2022)

Let \(f : \mathbb{R}^{2} \to \mathbb{R}\); assuming that \(f\) is differentiable, the partial derivative of \(f\) with respect to \(x\) is defined as
\[
\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} f(x, y) = \lim \limits_{\Delta x \to 0} \cfrac{f(x + \Delta x, y) - f(x, y)}{\Delta x}
\]
This stands for the analysis of variation in the direction of the \(x\)-axis (at point \(x\)) when the other direction (parallel to \(y\)-axis) is kept constant (at point y). This definition is illustrated for a particular case in figure 2: at the plane \(y = 0\), the function \(f(x, y) = x^{2} +y^{2}\) behaves as \(f(x, y = 0) = x^{2}\), which is the red curve; the partial derivative \(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} f(x, 0)\) is just the derivative of the parabola \(f(x, 0) = x^{2}\) in the direction of \(x\)-axis.



Figure 2: Graph of \(f(x, y) = x^{2} +y^{2}\). The red curve corresponds to the section \(y = 0\).


Analogously, one can also define the partial derivative of f with respect to y as
\[
\cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} f(x, y) = \lim \limits_{\Delta y \to 0} \cfrac{f(x, y + \Delta y) - f(x, y)}{\Delta y}
\]

title: 14  The n-dimensional space (\(\mathbb{R}^{n}\))
text:
14.3 Example of partial derivatives

Reference: Hase (2022)


\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} (x^{3} y^{2}) = 3x^{2} y^{2}\) (note that \(y\) was “kept constant” in this operation).
\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} (x^{3} y^{2}) = 2x^{3} y\) (note that \(x\) was “kept constant” in this operation).

The partial derivative shares the property of linearity present in ordinary derivatives. Furthermore, the product and quotient rules, and also the chain rule hold.

\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} (x y^{2} e^{x y}) = y^{2} e^{xy} + x y^{3} e^{xy}\) (note that \(y\) was “kept constant” in this operation).
\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} (x y^{2} e^{x y}) = 2 x y e^{xy} + x^{2} y^{2} e^{xy}\) (note that \(x\) was “kept constant” in this operation).
\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \left ( \cfrac{x + y}{y + 1} \right ) = \cfrac{1}{y + 1}\) (note that \(y\) was “kept constant” in this operation).
\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \left ( \cfrac{x + y}{y + 1} \right ) = \cfrac{1 - x}{(y + 1)^{2}}\) (note that \(x\) was “kept constant” in this operation).
\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} [\sin(x y) +\sin x] = y \cos(xy) + \cos x\) (note that \(y\) was “kept constant” in this operation).
\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} [\sin(x y) +\sin x] = x \cos(xy)\) (note that \(x\) was “kept constant” in this operation).

Partial derivatives of higher order can also be defined (trivially).

\(\cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}} e^{x y} = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \left [ \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} e^{x y} \right ] = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} [y e^{x y}] = y^{2} e^{x y}\)
\(\cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y^{2}} [\sin(x y) +\sin x] = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \left \{ \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} [\sin(x y) +\sin x] \right \} = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} [x \cos (x y)] = -x^{2} \sin(x y_)\)

In differential calculus of several variables, one can also define the mixed derivative. In this case, derivatives associated with different variables are taken.

\(\cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x \partial y} \sin (x y) = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \left [ \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \sin (x y) \right ] = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} [x \cos(x y)] = \cos (xy) - x y \sin(xy)\)
\(\cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y \partial x} \sin (x y) = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \left [ \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \sin (x y) \right ] = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} [y \cos(x y)] = \cos (xy) - x y \sin(xy)\)
\(\cfrac{\partial^{3}}{\partial x \partial y \partial z} e^{x y z} = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \left [ \cfrac{\partial}{\partial z} e^{x y z} \right ] = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} [x y e^{x y z}] = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} [(x + x^{2} y z) e^{x y z}] = (1 + 3xyz + x^{2} y^{2} z^{2}]) e^{x y z}]\)

Note that \(\cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x \partial y} = \cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y \partial x}\) in the two examples above. In principle, the derivatives of mixed derivatives do not commute, id est, \(\cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x \partial y} \neq \cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y \partial x}\); however, this situation will not be seen in this course.

title: 14  Functions of several variables
text:
14.1 The Taylor expasion

Reference: Hase (2022)

The Taylor expansion of a function \(f\) of several variables can be performed by expanding \(f\) for each variable separately (assuming all the pertinent derivatives). For instance, the Taylor expansion of \(f = f(x, y)\) at \((x, y) = (x_{0}, y_{0})\) can be determined by first noting that
\[
f(x, y) = f(x_{0}, y) + \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x_{0}, y) (x - x_{0}) + \cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y) (x - x_{0})^{2} + \cdots
\]
where terms of \(\mathcal{O} ((x − x_{0})^{3})\) were neglected. In the formula above, the expansion was performed on the variable \(x\) only.
Expanding now in the \(y\) variable leads to
\[
f(x, y) =
\overbrace{\left [ f(x_{0}, y_{0}) + \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (y - y_{0}) + \cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (y - y_{0})^{2} + \cdots \right ]}^{= f(x_{0}, y)} +
\]
\[
+ \overbrace{\left [ \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0}) + \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0}) (y - y_{0}) + \cdots \right ]}^{= \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x_{0}, y) (x - x_{0})} +
\overbrace{\left [ \cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0})^{2} + \cdots \right ]}^{= \cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y) (x - x_{0})^{2}} +
\cdots
\]
and rearranging the expression above yields
\[
f(x, y) =
f(x_{0}, y_{0}) + \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0}) +
\cfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (y - y_{0}) +
\]
\[
+
\cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0})^{2} +
\cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x \partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0}) (y - y_{0}) +
\cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (y - y_{0})^{2} +
\cdots
\]
This is the Taylor expansion of \(f = f(x, y)\) up to second order terms.

title: 14  Functions of several variables
text:
14.1 Analysis of local maxima/minima

Reference: Hase (2022)

A function can display local maxima and minima in its graph. The analysis of the local behaviors will be considered here but restricted to the case of two independent variables. Nevertheless, the analysis can be extended to functions of more variables with the same idea.
Let \(f : \mathbb{R}^{2} \to \mathbb{R}\) be a differentiable function with graph \(\{(x, y , z) \in \mathbb{R}^{3} : \mathcal{z} = f(x, y)\}\). It can display regions where the graph reaches local maximum or minimum values, and let \((x_{0}, y_{0})\) be one of these points. As in the calculus of a single variable, it is expected that the inclination of the tangent there would vanish. More precisely, the tangent plane at \((x_{0}, y_{0})\) would be parallel to the \(xy\) plane. This means that the critical points \((x_{0}, y_{0})\), which are solutions of
\[
\cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x, y) = \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x, y) = 0
\]
are candidates for local maximum or minimum. Hence, the formula above is a necessary condition to characterize an extremal point (maximum or minimum), but not a sufficient one. It is important to stress that

A point \(P(x_{0}, y_{0})\) is a local maximum if \(f(x, y) < f(x_{0}, y_{0})\) for any pair \((x, y)\) sufficiently close to \(P\) (but different from \(P\));
A point \(P(x_{0}, y_{0})\) is a local minimum if \(f(x, y) > f(x_{0}, y_{0})\) for any pair \((x, y)\) sufficiently close to \(P\) (but different from \(P\));

If \(P(x_{0}, y_{0})\) is an extremal point, the following analysis tells about its nature. The Taylor expansion of \(f\) around \(P\) leads to
\[
f(x, y) =
f(x_{0}, y_{0}) + \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0}) +
\cfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (y - y_{0}) +
\]
\[
+
\cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0})^{2} +
\cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x \partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0}) (y - y_{0}) +
\cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (y - y_{0})^{2} +
\cdots
\]
Inserting the two formulas above and introducing the notations
\[
A := \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}), \quad
B := \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x \partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}), \quad
C := \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}), \quad
\Delta x := x - x_{0} \quad and \quad
\Delta y := y - y_{0}
\]
one has
\[
\Delta f := f(x, y) - f(x_{0}, y_{0}) =
\cfrac{A}{2} \Delta x^{2} + B \Delta x \Delta y + \cfrac{C}{2} \Delta y^{2} + \mathcal{O} (\Delta x^{3}, \Delta y^{3})
\tag{i}
\]
For \(\Delta x\) and \(\Delta y\) sufficiently close to zero (which means that \((x, y)\) is close to \((x_{0}, y_{0})\)), the sign of \(\Delta f\) in the formula above is governed by \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\), as seen below. According to the definition above, \(\Delta f > 0\) and \(\Delta f < 0\) implies \((x_{0}, y_{0})\) being a local minimum and maximum, respectively.
The possible cases are listed below.
1. \(A \ \text{and} \ C \ \text{are not both zero}\). Assume that \(A \neq 0\) (the case \(C \neq 0\) can be worked out \(mutatis \ mutandis\)). Then, \(\Delta f\) can be cast as
\[
\Delta f = \cfrac{A}{2} \left [ \Delta x + \cfrac{B}{A} \Delta y \right ] + \cfrac{AC - B^{2}}{2A} \Delta y^{2} + \mathcal{O} (\Delta x^{3}, \Delta y^{3}) =
\]
\[
= \cfrac{A}{2} \Delta w^{2} + \cfrac{AC - B^{2}}{2A} \Delta y^{2} + \mathcal{O} (\Delta x^{3}, \Delta y^{3})
\]
where,
\[
\Delta w := \Delta x + \cfrac{B}{A} \Delta y
\]
The analysis will now be divided into some subcases.
(a).\(AC - B^{2} = 0\). In this case, no general conclusion can be stated about the nature of \((x_{0}, y_{0})\), since \(\Delta w\) can be zero without letting \(\Delta x = \Delta y = 0\) (which is the critical point). When this happens, the sign of \(\Delta f = \cfrac{A}{2} \Delta w^{2} + \mathcal{O} (\Delta x^{3}, \Delta y^{3}) = \mathcal{O} (\Delta x^{3}, \Delta y^{3})\) is decided by the third order terms, which requires further investigations.
(b).\(AC - B^{2} < 0\). In this case, the quadratic form in \((i)\) can be either positive or negative, depending on the chosen region in the neighborhood of \((x_{0}, y_{0})\). Therefore, the condition \(AC - B^{2}\) implies the critical point being a saddle-point.
(c).\(AC - B^{2} > 0\). In this case, both quadratic terms in \((i)\) have the same sign and the classification of the critical point depends on the sign of \(A\) only. If \(A > 0 \ (A < 0)\), then \(\Delta f > 0 \ (\Delta f < 0)\), which means that \((x_{0}, y_{0})\) is a local minimum (maximum).
2. \(A = C = 0\). Here, \(\Delta f = B \Delta x \Delta y + \mathcal{O} (\Delta x^{3}, \Delta y^{3})\). The analysis will now be divided into some subcases.
(a). If \(B = 0\), which implies \(AC - B^{2} = 0\), no general conclusion can be stated about the nature of \((x_{0}, y_{0})\), since it would depend on the third order terms.
(b). if \(B \neq 0\), which implies \(AC - B^{2} < 0\), the leading term, \(B \Delta x \Delta y\) can be either positive or negative, depending on the \((x_{0}, y_{0})\). In this situation, \((x_{0}, y_{0})\) is a saddle-point, where it can be seen as a local maximum according to some set of points \((x, y)\), but it can also be treated as a local minimum if another set of points \((x, y)\) is chosen.
All the cases above can be summarized by:
\[
A, B, C
\begin{cases}
AC - B^{2} = 0 \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \ \ \ : \quad \text{inconclusive (based on the second-order terms only)} \\
AC - B^{2} < 0 \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \ \ \ : \quad (x_{0}, y_{0}) \ \text{is a saddle point} \\
AC - B^{2} > 0 \ \text{and} \ A > 0 \quad : \quad (x_{0}, y_{0}) \ \text{is a local minimum} \\
AC - B^{2} > 0 \ \text{and} \ A < 0 \quad : \quad (x_{0}, y_{0}) \ \text{is a local maximum}
\end{cases}
\]
Note that \(AC − B^{2} > 0\) and \(A = 0\) are incompatible. Furthermore, \(AC − B^{2} > 0\) and \(A > 0\) imply \(C > 0\) (in the same fashion, \(AC − B^{2} > 0\) and \(A < 0\) lead to \(C < 0\)).
Example: Analyzing the critical points of \(f(x, y) = x^{3} − 3xy^{2} + y^{3} + 3y\)
Firstly, the critical points, which are solutions of
\[
\begin{cases}
\cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} = 3x^{2} - 3y^{2} = 0 \\
\cfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} = -6xy + 3y^{2} + 3 = 0
\end{cases}
\]
The critical points are \((−1, −1)\) or \((1, 1)\). Then, from
\[
A = \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) = 6x_{0}, \quad
B = \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x \partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}) = -6y_{0}, \quad \text{and} \quad
C = \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) = - 6x_{0} + 6y_{0}
\]
one sees that
\[
AC - B^{2} = 36y_{0} (- x^{2}_{0} + x_{0}y_{0} - y^{2}_{0}) =
\begin{cases}
\ \ 36 \quad \quad , \quad \text{if} \ (x_{0}, y_{0}) = (-1, -1) \\
\ - 36 \quad , \quad \text{if} \ (x_{0}, y_{0}) = (1, 1)
\end{cases}
\]
Thus, \((1, 1)\) is a saddle-point \(AC - B^{2} < 0\). Furthermore, \((−1, −1)\) is a local maximum point, since \(A = −6 < 0\) and \(AC - B^{2} < 0\).




Hase, Masayuki Oka. 2022. “Métodos Matemáticos e de Computação 1.”

title: 14  The n-dimensional space (\(\mathbb{R}^{n}\))
text:
14.1 Functions of several variables

Reference: Hase (2022)

So far, differential calculus has been applied to functions of a single variable; in the next section, it will be extended to two or more, which require some notions of functions of several real variables. Although one can investigate general functions of real variables like \(f ∶\mathbb{R}^{n} \to \mathbb{R}^{m}\), this course examines the case \(m = 1\) only. In this case, the graph of \(f\) is given by
\[
G_{f} = \{(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}, \mathcal{z}) \in \mathbb{R}^{n + 1} : \mathcal{z} = f(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}) \}
\]
where the case \(n = 2\) is an instructive one since one can visually sketch the graph. Some well-known graphs are depicted below.



Figure 1: Graph of some functions \(f: \mathbb{R}^{2} \to \mathbb{R}\). Left: an elliptic paraboloid \(f(x, y) = x^{2} + y^{2}\); center: an elliptic paraboloid \(f(x, y) = −x^{2} − y^{2}\); right: a hyperbolic paraboloid \(f(x, y) = y^{2} − x^{2}\).


The investigation of the variation of \(f\) is now a more complex task than in the single variable case since there is more than one direction (actually, there are infinite) to analyze the variation of \(f\). In cartesian coordinates, there are two natural directions (along the \(x\)-axis and \(y\)-axis) to consider, and a more general type of derivative is defined below.

title: 20  Analysis of local maxima/minima
text:
A function can display local maxima and minima in its graph. The analysis of the local behaviors will be considered here but restricted to the case of two independent variables. Nevertheless, the analysis can be extended to functions of more variables with the same idea.
Let \(f : \mathbb{R}^{2} \to \mathbb{R}\) be a differentiable function with graph \(\{(x, y , z) \in \mathbb{R}^{3} : \mathcal{z} = f(x, y)\}\). It can display regions where the graph reaches local maximum or minimum values, and let \((x_{0}, y_{0})\) be one of these points. As in the calculus of a single variable, it is expected that the inclination of the tangent there would vanish. More precisely, the tangent plane at \((x_{0}, y_{0})\) would be parallel to the \(xy\) plane. This means that the critical points \((x_{0}, y_{0})\), which are solutions of
\[
\cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x, y) = \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x, y) = 0
\]
are candidates for local maximum or minimum. Hence, the formula above is a necessary condition to characterize an extremal point (maximum or minimum), but not a sufficient one. It is important to stress that

A point \(P(x_{0}, y_{0})\) is a local maximum if \(f(x, y) < f(x_{0}, y_{0})\) for any pair \((x, y)\) sufficiently close to \(P\) (but different from \(P\));
A point \(P(x_{0}, y_{0})\) is a local minimum if \(f(x, y) > f(x_{0}, y_{0})\) for any pair \((x, y)\) sufficiently close to \(P\) (but different from \(P\));

If \(P(x_{0}, y_{0})\) is an extremal point, the following analysis tells about its nature. The Taylor expansion of \(f\) around \(P\) leads to
\[
f(x, y) =
f(x_{0}, y_{0}) + \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0}) +
\cfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (y - y_{0}) +
\]
\[
+
\cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0})^{2} +
\cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x \partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0}) (y - y_{0}) +
\cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (y - y_{0})^{2} +
\cdots
\]
Inserting the two formulas above and introducing the notations
\[
A := \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}), \quad
B := \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x \partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}), \quad
C := \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}), \quad
\Delta x := x - x_{0} \quad and \quad
\Delta y := y - y_{0}
\]
one has
\[
\Delta f := f(x, y) - f(x_{0}, y_{0}) =
\cfrac{A}{2} \Delta x^{2} + B \Delta x \Delta y + \cfrac{C}{2} \Delta y^{2} + \mathcal{O} (\Delta x^{3}, \Delta y^{3})
\tag{i}
\]
For \(\Delta x\) and \(\Delta y\) sufficiently close to zero (which means that \((x, y)\) is close to \((x_{0}, y_{0})\)), the sign of \(\Delta f\) in the formula above is governed by \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\), as seen below. According to the definition above, \(\Delta f > 0\) and \(\Delta f < 0\) implies \((x_{0}, y_{0})\) being a local minimum and maximum, respectively.
The possible cases are listed below.
\(\text{1}.\) \(A \ \text{and} \ C \ \text{are not both zero}\). Assume that \(A \neq 0\) (the case \(C \neq 0\) can be worked out \(mutatis \ mutandis\)). Then, \(\Delta f\) can be cast as
\[
\Delta f = \cfrac{A}{2} \left [ \Delta x + \cfrac{B}{A} \Delta y \right ] + \cfrac{AC - B^{2}}{2A} \Delta y^{2} + \mathcal{O} (\Delta x^{3}, \Delta y^{3}) =
\]
\[
= \cfrac{A}{2} \Delta w^{2} + \cfrac{AC - B^{2}}{2A} \Delta y^{2} + \mathcal{O} (\Delta x^{3}, \Delta y^{3})
\]
where,
\[
\Delta w := \Delta x + \cfrac{B}{A} \Delta y
\]
The analysis will now be divided into some subcases.
\((\text{a})\) \(AC - B^{2} = 0\). In this case, no general conclusion can be stated about the nature of \((x_{0}, y_{0})\), since \(\Delta w\) can be zero without letting \(\Delta x = \Delta y = 0\) (which is the critical point). When this happens, the sign of \(\Delta f = \cfrac{A}{2} \Delta w^{2} + \mathcal{O} (\Delta x^{3}, \Delta y^{3}) = \mathcal{O} (\Delta x^{3}, \Delta y^{3})\) is decided by the third order terms, which requires further investigations.
\((\text{b})\) \(AC - B^{2} < 0\). In this case, the quadratic form in \(\text{(i)}\) can be either positive or negative, depending on the chosen region in the neighborhood of \((x_{0}, y_{0})\). Therefore, the condition \(AC - B^{2}\) implies the critical point being a saddle-point.
\((\text{c})\) \(AC - B^{2} > 0\). In this case, both quadratic terms in \(\text{(i)}\) have the same sign and the classification of the critical point depends on the sign of \(A\) only. If \(A > 0 \ (A < 0)\), then \(\Delta f > 0 \ (\Delta f < 0)\), which means that \((x_{0}, y_{0})\) is a local minimum (maximum).
\(\text{2}.\) \(A = C = 0\). Here, \(\Delta f = B \Delta x \Delta y + \mathcal{O} (\Delta x^{3}, \Delta y^{3})\). The analysis will now be divided into some subcases.
\((\text{a})\) If \(B = 0\), which implies \(AC - B^{2} = 0\), no general conclusion can be stated about the nature of \((x_{0}, y_{0})\), since it would depend on the third order terms.
\((\text{b})\) if \(B \neq 0\), which implies \(AC - B^{2} < 0\), the leading term, \(B \Delta x \Delta y\) can be either positive or negative, depending on the \((x_{0}, y_{0})\). In this situation, \((x_{0}, y_{0})\) is a saddle-point, where it can be seen as a local maximum according to some set of points \((x, y)\), but it can also be treated as a local minimum if another set of points \((x, y)\) is chosen.
All the cases above can be summarized by:
\[
A, B, C
\begin{cases}
AC - B^{2} = 0 \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \ \ \ : \quad \text{inconclusive (based on the second-order terms only)} \\
AC - B^{2} < 0 \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \ \ \ : \quad (x_{0}, y_{0}) \ \text{is a saddle point} \\
AC - B^{2} > 0 \ \text{and} \ A > 0 \quad : \quad (x_{0}, y_{0}) \ \text{is a local minimum} \\
AC - B^{2} > 0 \ \text{and} \ A < 0 \quad : \quad (x_{0}, y_{0}) \ \text{is a local maximum}
\end{cases}
\]
Note that \(AC − B^{2} > 0\) and \(A = 0\) are incompatible. Furthermore, \(AC − B^{2} > 0\) and \(A > 0\) imply \(C > 0\) (in the same fashion, \(AC − B^{2} > 0\) and \(A < 0\) lead to \(C < 0\)).
Example: Analyzing the critical points of \(f(x, y) = x^{3} − 3xy^{2} + y^{3} + 3y\)
Firstly, the critical points, which are solutions of
\[
\begin{cases}
\cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} = 3x^{2} - 3y^{2} = 0 \\
\cfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} = -6xy + 3y^{2} + 3 = 0
\end{cases}
\]
The critical points are \((−1, −1)\) or \((1, 1)\). Then, from
\[
A = \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) = 6x_{0}, \quad
B = \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x \partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}) = -6y_{0}, \quad \text{and} \quad
C = \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) = - 6x_{0} + 6y_{0}
\]
one sees that
\[
AC - B^{2} = 36y_{0} (- x^{2}_{0} + x_{0}y_{0} - y^{2}_{0}) =
\begin{cases}
\ \ 36 \quad \quad , \quad \text{if} \ (x_{0}, y_{0}) = (-1, -1) \\
\ - 36 \quad , \quad \text{if} \ (x_{0}, y_{0}) = (1, 1)
\end{cases}
\]
Thus, \((1, 1)\) is a saddle-point \(AC - B^{2} < 0\). Furthermore, \((−1, −1)\) is a local maximum point, since \(A = −6 < 0\) and \(AC - B^{2} < 0\).




Hase, Masayuki Oka. 2022. “Métodos Matemáticos e de Computação 1.”

title: 16  The Taylor expasion
text:
The Taylor expansion of a function \(f\) of several variables can be performed by expanding \(f\) for each variable separately (assuming all the pertinent derivatives). For instance, the Taylor expansion of \(f = f(x, y)\) at \((x, y) = (x_{0}, y_{0})\) can be determined by first noting that
\[
f(x, y) = f(x_{0}, y) + \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x_{0}, y) (x - x_{0}) + \cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y) (x - x_{0})^{2} + \cdots
\]
where terms of \(\mathcal{O} ((x − x_{0})^{3})\) were neglected. In the formula above, the expansion was performed on the variable \(x\) only.
Expanding now in the \(y\) variable leads to
\[
f(x, y) =
\overbrace{\left [ f(x_{0}, y_{0}) + \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (y - y_{0}) + \cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (y - y_{0})^{2} + \cdots \right ]}^{= f(x_{0}, y)} +
\]
\[
+ \overbrace{\left [ \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0}) + \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0}) (y - y_{0}) + \cdots \right ]}^{= \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x_{0}, y) (x - x_{0})} +
\overbrace{\left [ \cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0})^{2} + \cdots \right ]}^{= \cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y) (x - x_{0})^{2}} +
\cdots
\]
and rearranging the expression above yields
\[
f(x, y) =
f(x_{0}, y_{0}) + \cfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0}) +
\cfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (y - y_{0}) +
\]
\[
+
\cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0})^{2} +
\cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x \partial y} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (x - x_{0}) (y - y_{0}) +
\cfrac{1}{2!} \cfrac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y^{2}} (x_{0}, y_{0}) (y - y_{0})^{2} +
\cdots
\]
This is the Taylor expansion of \(f = f(x, y)\) up to second order terms.




Hase, Masayuki Oka. 2022. “Métodos Matemáticos e de Computação 1.”

title: 18  Partial derivatives
text:
Reference: Hase (2022)
Let \(f : \mathbb{R}^{2} \to \mathbb{R}\); assuming that \(f\) is differentiable, the partial derivative of \(f\) with respect to \(x\) is defined as
\[
\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} f(x, y) = \lim \limits_{\Delta x \to 0} \cfrac{f(x + \Delta x, y) - f(x, y)}{\Delta x}
\]
This stands for the analysis of variation in the direction of the \(x\)-axis (at point \(x\)) when the other direction (parallel to \(y\)-axis) is kept constant (at point \(y\)). This definition is illustrated for a particular case in figure 1: at the plane \(y = 0\), the function \(f(x, y) = x^{2} +y^{2}\) behaves as \(f(x, y = 0) = x^{2}\), which is the red curve; the partial derivative \(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} f(x, 0)\) is just the derivative of the parabola \(f(x, 0) = x^{2}\) in the direction of \(x\)-axis.
Analogously, one can also define the partial derivative of f with respect to y as
\[
\cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} f(x, y) = \lim \limits_{\Delta y \to 0} \cfrac{f(x, y + \Delta y) - f(x, y)}{\Delta y}
\]

title: 18  Partial derivatives
text:
18.1 Example of partial derivatives

Reference: Hase (2022)


\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} (x^{3} y^{2}) = 3x^{2} y^{2}\) (note that \(y\) was “kept constant” in this operation).
\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} (x^{3} y^{2}) = 2x^{3} y\) (note that \(x\) was “kept constant” in this operation).

The partial derivative shares the property of linearity present in ordinary derivatives. Furthermore, the product and quotient rules, and also the chain rule hold.

\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} (x y^{2} e^{x y}) = y^{2} e^{xy} + x y^{3} e^{xy}\) (note that \(y\) was “kept constant” in this operation).
\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} (x y^{2} e^{x y}) = 2 x y e^{xy} + x^{2} y^{2} e^{xy}\) (note that \(x\) was “kept constant” in this operation).
\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \left ( \cfrac{x + y}{y + 1} \right ) = \cfrac{1}{y + 1}\) (note that \(y\) was “kept constant” in this operation).
\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \left ( \cfrac{x + y}{y + 1} \right ) = \cfrac{1 - x}{(y + 1)^{2}}\) (note that \(x\) was “kept constant” in this operation).
\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} [\sin(x y) +\sin x] = y \cos(xy) + \cos x\) (note that \(y\) was “kept constant” in this operation).
\(\cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} [\sin(x y) +\sin x] = x \cos(xy)\) (note that \(x\) was “kept constant” in this operation).

Partial derivatives of higher order can also be defined (trivially).

\(\cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}} e^{x y} = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \left [ \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} e^{x y} \right ] = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} [y e^{x y}] = y^{2} e^{x y}\)
\(\cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y^{2}} [\sin(x y) +\sin x] = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \left \{ \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} [\sin(x y) +\sin x] \right \} = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} [x \cos (x y)] = -x^{2} \sin(x y_)\)

In differential calculus of several variables, one can also define the mixed derivative. In this case, derivatives associated with different variables are taken.

\(\cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x \partial y} \sin (x y) = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \left [ \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \sin (x y) \right ] = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} [x \cos(x y)] = \cos (xy) - x y \sin(xy)\)
\(\cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y \partial x} \sin (x y) = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \left [ \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \sin (x y) \right ] = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} [y \cos(x y)] = \cos (xy) - x y \sin(xy)\)
\(\cfrac{\partial^{3}}{\partial x \partial y \partial z} e^{x y z} = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \left [ \cfrac{\partial}{\partial z} e^{x y z} \right ] = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y} [x y e^{x y z}] = \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x} [(x + x^{2} y z) e^{x y z}] = (1 + 3xyz + x^{2} y^{2} z^{2}]) e^{x y z}]\)

Note that \(\cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x \partial y} = \cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y \partial x}\) in the two examples above. In principle, the derivatives of mixed derivatives do not commute, id est, \(\cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x \partial y} \neq \cfrac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y \partial x}\); however, this situation will not be seen in this course.




Hase, Masayuki Oka. 2022. “Métodos Matemáticos e de Computação 1.”

title: 15  Functions of several variables
text:
Although one can investigate general functions of real variables like \(f ∶\mathbb{R}^{n} \to \mathbb{R}^{m}\), this chapter examines the case \(m = 1\) only. In this case, the graph of \(f\) is given by
\[
G_{f} = \{(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}, \mathcal{z}) \in \mathbb{R}^{n + 1} : \mathcal{z} = f(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}) \}
\]
where the case \(n = 2\) is an instructive one since one can visually sketch the graph.
Some well-known graphs are depicted below.



Figure 1: Graph of some functions \(f: \mathbb{R}^{2} \to \mathbb{R}\). Left: an elliptic paraboloid \(f(x, y) = x^{2} + y^{2}\); center: an elliptic paraboloid \(f(x, y) = −x^{2} − y^{2}\); right: a hyperbolic paraboloid \(f(x, y) = y^{2} − x^{2}\).


The investigation of the variation of \(f\) is now a more complex task than in the single variable case since there is more than one direction (actually, there are infinite) to analyze the variation of \(f\). In cartesian coordinates, there are two natural directions (along the \(x\)-axis and \(y\)-axis) to consider, and a more general type of derivative is in the partial derivatives chapter.

13.3 Elementary functions
Podemos obter as integrais indefinidas das principais funções, que decorrem imediatamente das respectivas regras de derivação:

\(\int x^{n} dx = \cfrac {x^{n + 1}}{n+1} + c\), \(\forall n \in \mathbb{Z} \mid n \neq -1\), pois a derivada de \(\cfrac {x^{n + 1}} {n+1}\) é \(x^{n}\)

Observe que se \(x < 0\) , \(\int \cfrac {1} {x} \ dx = \ln (-x) + c\)
Assim, de modo geral, podemos escrever: \(\int \frac {1} {x} \ dx = \ln |x| + c\)
Para qualquer real \(\alpha \neq -1\), \(\int x^{a} \ dx = \cfrac {x^{\alpha + 1}} {\alpha + 1} + c\), \((x > 0)\)
\(\int \cos xdx = \sin x + c\), pois a derivada de \(\sin x\) é \(\cos x\)

13.4 General formulas

Reference: Hass, Heil, and Weir (2018)


Zero: \(\displaystyle \int^{a}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = 0\)
Order of integration: \(\displaystyle \int^{a}_{b} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = - \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x\)
Constant multiples:

\(\displaystyle \int^{b}_{a} k f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = k \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x, \quad k \in \mathbb{R}\)
\(\displaystyle \int^{b}_{a} - f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = - \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x, \quad k = -1\)

Sum: \(\displaystyle \int^{b}_{a} [(f(x) + g(x)] \ \mathrm{d} x = \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x + \int^{b}_{a} g(x) \ \mathrm{d} x\)
Difference: \(\displaystyle \int^{b}_{a} [(f(x) - g(x)] \ \mathrm{d} x = \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x - \int^{b}_{a} g(x) \ \mathrm{d} x\)
Additivity: \(\displaystyle \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x + \int \limits^{c}_{b} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = \int \limits^{c}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x\)
Max-min inequality: If max \(f\) and min \(f\) are the maximum and minimum values of \(f\) on \([a, b]\), then

\[
\text{min} \ f \cdot (b - a) \leq \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x \leq \text{max} \ f \cdot (b - a)
\]

Domination:

\(\displaystyle f(x) \geq g(x) \quad \text{on} \quad [a, b] \quad \text{implies} \quad \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x \geq \int^{b}_{a} g(x) \ \mathrm{d} x\)
\(\displaystyle f(x) \geq 0 \quad \text{on} \quad [a, b] \quad \text{implies} \quad \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x \geq 0\)

title: 13  Integrals
text:
13.3 (Riemann) Integral definition

Reference: Hase (2022)

lef \(f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}\) be a continuous function. Considering an interval \([a, b] \subset \mathbb{R}\), it is possible to choose a partition given by \(a = x_{0} < x_{1} < \cdots < x_{N - 1} < x_{N} = b\) (figure 1) from which one can define the sum
\[
\sum \limits^{N}_{n = 1}  f(x_{n}) \Delta x_{n} \quad \text{where} \quad \Delta x_{n} := x_{n} - x_{n - 1}
\]
Note that if \(f \geq 0\) in \([a, b]\), this sum approaches the area between \(f\) and the \(x\) axis when
\(\text{(a)}\) The size of each division is diminished.
\(\text{(b)}\) The number of divisions inside the partition is increased.



Figure 1: Decomposition in rectangles


It should be clear that \(\text{(a)}\) implies \(\text{(b)}\), but the converse is false. The limit of such sum is the (Riemann) integral of \(f\) in the interval \([a, b]\), and is denoted by
\[
\int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x := \lim \limits_{\text{max}_{n} \ \Delta x_{n} \to 0} \sum \limits^{N}_{n = 1}  f(x_{n}) \Delta x_{n}
\]
The interpretation of the formula above as being the area becomes clearer if the quantity \(\displaystyle \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x\) is understood as \(\displaystyle \int^{b}_{a} [f(x) - 0] \ \mathrm{d} x\). Hence, if \(f \leq 0\) at \([a, b]\), \(\displaystyle \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x\) would be the “opposite of the area”. The continuity condition of f can be relaxed to piecewise continuity.
Two properties of the definite integral are assumed by definition:

\(\displaystyle \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = - \int^{a}_{b} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x\)
\(\displaystyle \int^{a}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = 0\)

title: 13  Integrals
text:
13.3 (Riemann) Integral - Definition

Reference: Hase (2022)

Let \(f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}\) be a continuous function. Considering an interval \([a, b] \subset \mathbb{R}\), it is possible to choose a partition given by \(a = x_{0} < x_{1} < \cdots < x_{N - 1} < x_{N} = b\) (figure 1) from which one can define the sum
\[
\sum \limits^{N}_{n = 1}  f(x_{n}) \Delta x_{n} \quad \text{where} \quad \Delta x_{n} := x_{n} - x_{n - 1}
\]
Note that if \(f \geq 0\) in \([a, b]\), this sum approaches the area between \(f\) and the \(x\) axis when
\(\text{(a)}\) The size of each division is diminished.
\(\text{(b)}\) The number of divisions inside the partition is increased.



Figure 1: Decomposition in rectangles


It should be clear that \(\text{(a)}\) implies \(\text{(b)}\), but the converse is false. The limit of such sum is the (Riemann) integral of \(f\) in the interval \([a, b]\), and is denoted by
\[
\int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x := \lim \limits_{\text{max}_{n} \ \Delta x_{n} \to 0} \sum \limits^{N}_{n = 1}  f(x_{n}) \Delta x_{n}
\]
The interpretation of the formula above as being the area becomes clearer if the quantity \(\displaystyle \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x\) is understood as \(\displaystyle \int^{b}_{a} [f(x) - 0] \ \mathrm{d} x\). Hence, if \(f \leq 0\) at \([a, b]\), \(\displaystyle \int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x\) would be the “opposite of the area”. The continuity condition of \(f\) can be relaxed to piecewise continuity.
Two properties of the definite integral are assumed by definition:
\[
\int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = - \int^{a}_{b} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x
\tag{i}
\]
\[
\int^{a}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = 0
\tag{ii}
\]

title: 13  Integrals
text:
13.5 (Riemann) Integral - Fundamental theorem of calculus

Reference: Hase (2022)

This section establishes a connection between the integral of a function and its derivative. Concretely, this connection allows one to evaluate some integrals in terms of some known functions.
Let \(f\) be continuous in \(\mathbb{R}\) (for simplicity) and consider the function
\[
F(x) := \int^{x}_{a} f(\xi) \ \mathrm{d} \xi
\tag{iii}
\]
which represents the integral of \(f\) from point \(a\) (fixed) to another point \(x\) (variable). Then, from the properties shown in the section above, it follow that
\[
\cfrac{F(x + \Delta x) - F(x)}{\Delta x} =
\cfrac{1}{\Delta x} \left [ \int^{x + \Delta x}_{a} f(\xi) \ \mathrm{d} \xi - \int^{x}_{a} f(\xi) \ \mathrm{d} \xi \right ] =
\cfrac{1}{\Delta x} \int^{x + \Delta x}_{x} f(\xi) \ \mathrm{d} \xi
\]
The integral above is evaluated in the interval \([x, x + \Delta x)\); if the value of \(\Delta x \ (> 0)\) is decreased, one has \(f(\xi) \approx f(x)\) for \(\xi \in [x, x + \Delta x)\), since \(f\) is continuous. Therefore,
\[
\cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} x} F(x) =
\lim \limits_{\Delta x \to 0} \cfrac{F(x + \Delta x) - F(x)}{\Delta x} =
\lim \limits_{\Delta x \to 0} \cfrac{1}{\Delta x} \int^{x + \Delta x}_{a} \underbrace{f(\xi)}_{\simeq f(x)} \ \mathrm{d} \xi =
\]
\[
= \lim \limits_{\Delta x \to 0} \cfrac{1}{\Delta x} f(x) \int^{x + \Delta x}_{a}  \mathrm{d} x = f(x)
\]
remembering that the integral (in the variable \(\xi\)) does not act over \(f(x)\), which is considered to be “constant”; moreover, \(\displaystyle \int^{x + \Delta x}_{a} \mathrm{d} \xi = \int^{x + \Delta x}_{a} 1 \ \mathrm{d} \xi\) is the area of the rectangle defined between the constant function \(1\) and the \(x\)-axis in the interval \(\xi \in [x, x + \Delta x)\). As a consequence, one has
\[
\cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} x} \int^{x}_{a} f(\xi) \ \mathrm{d} \xi = f(x)
\tag{iv}
\]
Note that this result does not depend on the choice of \(a\).
Suppose, now, that there is a function \(g\) such that \(f = g'\). This means that both \(F\) and \(g\) are antiderivatives of \(f\). From \(\text{(iii)}\) and \(\text{(iv)}\), one has \(F' = f = g'\) and, from the linearity of derivatives, \((F − g)' = 0\). Hence, the function \(F − g\) should equal a constant, \(c \in \mathbb{R}\), from which
\[
F(x) = g(x) + c \quad (x \in \mathbb{R})
\]
Since \(F(a) = 0\) by \(\text{(iii)}\), it is straightforward that \(c = − g(a)\); then, \(F(x) = g(x) − g(a)\) by the formula above. Finally, by choosing \(x = b\) in \(\text{(iii)}\), which implies \(F(b) = g(b) − b(a)\), one has
\[
\int^{b}_{a} f(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = g(b) - g(a), \quad \text{where} \quad f = g'
\]
This is the definite integral, which is a “number”(indefinite integrals are families of functions). To evaluate the integral of \(f\) from \(a\) to \(b\), it is necessary, then, to find a function \(g\) whose derivative is \(f\) and compute the difference \(g(b) − g(a)\). Finally, one also has
\[
\int^{b}_{a} \left [ \cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} x} f(x) \right ] \ \mathrm{d} x = \int^{b}_{a} f'(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = f(b) - f(a)
\]
since \(f\) is a function whose derivative is \(f'\).
Example: \(\displaystyle \int^{\pi}_{0} \sin x \ \mathrm{d} x\)
Firstly,
\[
\int^{\pi}_{0} \sin x \ \mathrm{d} x = F(\pi) - F(0)
\]
where \(F\) is such that \(F' = f\). Therefore, taking \(F(x) = − \cos x\) is a possibility (actually \(\cos x + c\), \(c \in \mathbb{R}\), also works, but the constant \(c\) plays no role, since it cancels out in the difference \(F(\pi) - F(0)\)); as a consequence,
\[
\int^{\pi}_{0} \sin x \ \mathrm{d} x = [- \cos \pi] - [- \cos 0] = 2
\]
Example: \(\displaystyle \int^{3}_{1} \left ( \cfrac{x^{3} - x}{x} \right ) \ \mathrm{d} x\)
Since \(\cfrac{x^{3} - x}{x} = \cfrac{x^{3}}{x} - \cfrac{x}{x} = x^{2} - 1\) (for \(x \neq 0\)), then,
\[
\int^{3}_{1} \left ( \cfrac{x^{3} - x}{x} \right ) \ \mathrm{d} x =
\int^{3}_{1} x^{2} \ \mathrm{d} x - \int^{3}_{1} 1 \ \mathrm{d} x =
\]
\[
= \biggr [ \underbrace{\cfrac{x^{3}}{3}}_{\text{antiderivative of} \ x^{2}} \biggr ]^{3}_{1} - \biggr [ \underbrace{x}_{\text{antiderivative of} \ 1} \biggr ]^{3}_{1} =
\biggr [ \cfrac{3^{3}}{3} - \cfrac{1^{3}}{3} \biggr ] - \biggr [ 3 - 1 \biggr ] = \cfrac{20}{3}
\]




Hase, Masayuki Oka. 2022. “Métodos Matemáticos e de Computação 1.”

title: 14  Integration techniques
text:
Reference: Hase (2022)

Consider the integral
\[
\int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{0} \cos(2x) \ \mathrm{d} x
\tag{1}
\]
Although the integral
\[
\int \cos(\xi) \ \mathrm{d} \xi = \sin \xi \quad (+c \in \mathbb{R})
\quad \text{and/or} \quad
\int^{b}_{a} \cos(\xi) \ \mathrm{d} \xi = \sin b - \sin a
\]
is a well-known one, the main difficulty that precludes a simple evaluation of \((1)\) is, at a first glance, the argument of the cosine function \((2x)\), which is not “in accordance” with the measure \(\mathrm{d} x\). This is a typical example that requires the technique of integration by substitution.
The resolution of \((1)\) requires a strategy that transforms it into a known elementary integral. This procedure demands three steps:

Definition of a new suitable variable.

Firstly, one may define
\[
u(x) := 2x
\]
It is clear that this choice leads to “\(\cos u\)” instead of “\(\cos(2x)\)”. This fact suggests an approximation to a known integral.

Change of measure.

With the introduction of the (new) variable \(u\), the integration can not be performed with the measure \(\mathrm{d} x\) anymore. To introduce the measure “\(\mathrm{d} u\)”, note that
\[
\cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} x} u(x) = 2
\]
from which
\[
\mathrm{d} u = 2 \mathrm{d} x \quad \text{or} \quad \mathrm{d} x = \cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{d} u
\]

Change of the domain of integration.

Since the integral of \((1)\) is evaluated in the interval that runs from \(0\) to \(\cfrac{\pi}{2}\) for the \(x\) variable, one should find the corresponding extremal points for the new variable \(u\):
\[
\begin{cases}
x = 0 \quad \ \ \longrightarrow \quad u(x = 0) = 2 \cdot 0 = 0 \\
x = \cfrac{\pi}{2} \quad \longrightarrow \quad u(x = \cfrac{\pi}{2}) = 2 \cdot \cfrac{\pi}{2} = \pi
\end{cases}
\]
The three steps above lead to
\[
\int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{0} \cos(2x) \ \mathrm{d} x =
\int^{\pi}_{0} \cos u \left ( \cfrac{1}{2} \ \mathrm{d} u \right ) =
\cfrac{1}{2} \int^{\pi}_{0} \cos u \ \mathrm{d} u =
\cfrac{1}{2} \biggr [ \sin u \biggr ]^{\pi}_{0}
\]
This technique can be summarized by the two formulas below.

Tip: For definite integrals, use the first formula and then compute the definite value.

\[
\int f(g(x)) \cdot g'(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = \int f(u) \ \mathrm{d} u
\]
\[
\int^{b}_{a} f(g(x)) \cdot g'(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = \int^{g(b)}_{g(a)} f(u) \ \mathrm{d} u
\]

title: 14  Integration techniques
text:
14.4 Integration by parts

Reference: Hase (2022)

Consider the integral
\[
\int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{0} x \cos x \ \mathrm{d} x
\tag{3}
\]
Although the integral
\[
\int \cos(\xi) \ \mathrm{d} \xi = \sin \xi \quad (+c \in \mathbb{R})
\quad \text{and/or} \quad
\int^{b}_{a} \cos(\xi) \ \mathrm{d} \xi = \sin b - \sin a
\]
can be solved, the main issue that precludes the computation of \((3)\) is, at a first glance, the presence of an “extra term” in the integrand (\(x\)). A possible strategy to solve this kind of integral is the integration by parts.
Before presenting this technique, it is convenient to remember the product rule for derivatives, which is
\[
\cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} [u(x) v(x)] =
v(x) \cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} u(x) + u(x) \cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} v(x)
\]
Integrating both sides in the interval \([a, b]\) leads to
\[
\int^{b}_{a} \cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} [u(x) v(x)] =
\int^{b}_{a} v(x) \cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} u(x) +
\int^{b}_{a} u(x) \cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} v(x)
\]
which can be cast as
\[
\biggr [ u(x) v(x) \biggr ]^{b}_{a} =
\int^{b}_{a} v(x) u'(x) + \int^{b}_{a} u(x) v'(x)
\]
or, finally,
\[
\int^{b}_{a} u(x) v'(x) =
\biggr [ u(x) v(x) \biggr ]^{b}_{a} - \int^{b}_{a} u'(x) v(x)
\]
For indefinite integrals, one has
\[
\int u(x) v'(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = u(x) v(x) - \int u'(x) v(x) \ \mathrm{d} x + c \quad (c \in \mathbb{R})
\]
To summarize, using \(u(x) = f(x)\) and \(v(x) = g(x)\), we can have

Tip: For definite integrals, use the first formula and then compute the definite value.

\[
\int f(x) g'(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = f(x) g(x) -\int f'(x) g(x) \ \mathrm{d} x  + c \quad (c \in \mathbb{R})
\]
\[
\int^{b}_{a} f(x) g'(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = \biggr [ f(x) g(x) \biggr ]^{b}_{a} -\int^{b}_{a} f'(x) g(x) \ \mathrm{d} x
\tag{4}
\]
The strategy to solve \((3)\) is transforming it into another integral that is analytically accessible. One should first define the functions that correspond to \(f\) and \(g'\). Taking
\[
\begin{cases}
f(x) \ = x \\
g'(x) = \cos (x)
\end{cases}
\quad \text{, then} \quad
\begin{cases}
f'(x) = 1 \\
g(x) \ = \sin x
\end{cases}
\]
Hence,
\[
\int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{0} \overbrace{x}^{f} \overbrace{\cos x}^{g'} \ \mathrm{d} x =
\biggr [ \overbrace{x}^{f} \overbrace{\sin x}^{g} \biggr ]^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{0} - \int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{0} \overbrace{1}^{f'} \cdot \overbrace{\sin x}^{g} \ \mathrm{d} x =
\cfrac{\pi}{2} - 1
\]
Note that the determination of \(g(x)\) from \(g'(x)\) requires an antiderivative, and the integration constant can be ignored; this procedure is usually adopted since this constant is canceled out, as one can see from \((4)\) by replacing \(g\) for \(g + c\) in the right-hand side:
\[
\int^{b}_{a} f(x) g'(x) \ \mathrm{d} x = \biggr [ f(x) g(x) \biggr ]^{b}_{a} - \int^{b}_{a} f'(x) g(x) \ \mathrm{d} x =
\]
\[
= \biggr [ f(x) (g(x) + c) \biggr ]^{b}_{a} - \int^{b}_{a} f'(x) (g(x) + c) \ \mathrm{d} x =
\]
\[
= \biggr [ f(x) g(x) \biggr ]^{b}_{a} + c \biggr [ f(x) \biggr ]^{b}_{a} - c \int^{b}_{a} f'(x) \ \mathrm{d} x - \int^{b}_{a} f'(x) g(x) \ \mathrm{d} x =
\]
\[
= \biggr [ f(x) g(x) \biggr ]^{b}_{a} + c \biggr [ f(x) \biggr ]^{b}_{a} - c \biggr [ f(x) \biggr ]^{b}_{a} - \int^{b}_{a} f'(x) g(x) \ \mathrm{d} x =
\]
\[
= \biggr [ f(x) g(x) \biggr ]^{b}_{a} - \int^{b}_{a} f'(x) g(x) \ \mathrm{d} x
\]

title: 14  Integration techniques
text:
14.6 Integration by partial fractions
Let \(R\) be a rational fraction of a single variable, id est, a fraction where both numerator and denominator are polynomials. A partial fraction decomposition of \(R\) is its representation in terms of a polynomial and a sum of fractions of simpler denominators. Concretely, one has
\[
R(x) = P(x) + \sum \limits_{i} \cfrac{N_{i}(x)}{D_{i}(x)}
\]
where \(P\), \(\{N_{i}\}\) and \(\{D_{i}\}\) are polynomials. It is important to stress that in this representation, the degree of polynomial \(N_{i}\) is strictly smaller than the degree of \(D_{i}\), which is a power of an irreducible polynomial (id est, it is not factorable into other polynomials). Note that in the formula above, \(P\) can be zero. As an example, one has
\[
\cfrac{x^{2} + 1}{(x - 1)^{2} (x - 2)} = \cfrac{(-4x + 2)}{(x - 1)^{2}} + \cfrac{5}{x - 2}
\]
The procedure to obtain this kind of representation is illustrated below.
Consider, now, the integral
\[
\int \cfrac{\mathrm{d} x}{x (x - 1)}
\]
When the integrand has a polynomial in its denominator, the integral can be tackled, sometimes, by the method of partial fractions. The main idea is finding a decomposition that breaks the original fraction into simpler ones. In the present case, one should invoke an identity of the form
\[
\cfrac{1}{x (x - 1)} = \cfrac{A}{x} + \cfrac{B}{x - 1}
\]
where \(A\) and \(B\) are polynomials with degrees smaller than their denominators. The equation above can be written as
\[
\cfrac{0 \cdot x + 1}{x (x - 1)} = \cfrac{A}{x} + \cfrac{B}{x + 1} =
\cfrac{A (x - 1) + Bx}{x (x - 1)} =
\]
\[
= \cfrac{Ax - A + Bx}{x (x - 1)} =
\cfrac{(A + B) x + (-A)}{x (x - 1)}
\]
Identifying the polynomials of the numerators, one has the linear system
\[
\begin{cases} 0 = A + B \\ 1 = - A \end{cases} \quad , \quad
\text{from which} \quad A = -1 \quad \text{and} \quad B = 1
\]
Then, one finds
\[
\cfrac{1}{x (x - 1)} = \cfrac{1}{x} + \cfrac{1}{x - 1}
\]
consequently,
\[
\int \cfrac{1}{x (x - 1)} \ \mathrm{dx} =
\int \left ( - \cfrac{1}{x} + \cfrac{1}{x - 1} \right ) \ \mathrm{dx} =
\]
\[
= - \int \cfrac{1}{x} \ \mathrm{dx} + \int \cfrac{1}{x - 1} \ \mathrm{dx} =
- \ln|x| + \ln|x - 1| + c \quad , \quad c \in \mathbb{R}
\]

title: 14  Integration techniques
text:
14.2 Example of integration by substitution

Reference: Hase (2022)

Consider the integral
\[
\int \cfrac{1}{\pi x + 1} \ \mathrm{d} x
\]
Introducing \(u(x) := \pi x + 1\), one has \(\cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} u(x) = \pi\), from which \(\mathrm{d} u = \pi \ \mathrm{d} x\) or \(\mathrm{d} x = \cfrac{1}{\pi} \mathrm{d}u\). Then,
\[
\int \cfrac{1}{\pi x + 1} \ \mathrm{d} x =
\int \cfrac{1}{u} \left ( \cfrac{1}{\pi} \mathrm{d} u \right ) =
\cfrac{1}{\pi} \int \cfrac{1}{u} \mathrm{d} u =
\cfrac{1}{\pi} \ \ln|u| + c \quad (c \in \mathbb{R})
\]
Finally, the variable \(u\) was introduced for convenience, and one should return to the original variable \(x\). Since \(u = \pi x + 1\), then,
\[
\int \cfrac{1}{\pi x + 1} \ \mathrm{d} x =
\cfrac{1}{\pi} \ \ln|\overbrace{\pi x + 1}^{= u}| + c \quad (c \in \mathbb{R})
\]

title: 14  Integration techniques
text:
14.3 Principal part
Consider the integral
\[
\int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{0} e^{-\tan x} \sec^{2}x \ \mathrm{d} x
\]
Introducing \(u(x) := −\tan x\), one has \(\cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} u(x) = - \sec^{2}x\), from which \(- \mathrm{d} u = \sec^{2}x \ \mathrm{d} x\) or \(\mathrm{d} x = - \cfrac{1}{\sec^{2}x} \ \mathrm{d} u\). Then,
\[
\begin{cases}
x = 0 \quad \ \ \longrightarrow \quad u(x = 0) = - \tan 0 = 0 \\
x = \cfrac{\pi}{2} \quad \longrightarrow \quad u(x = \cfrac{\pi}{2}) = - \tan  \cfrac{\pi}{2} = - \infty
\end{cases}
\]
In this case, one should consider the tangent function in its principal interval, \(- \cfrac{\pi}{2} < x < \cfrac{\pi}{2}\). Consequently, “\(x = \cfrac{\pi}{2}\)” means \(x \to \cfrac{\pi}{2}^{-}\) and \(u(\cfrac{\pi}{2}) = - \lim \limits_{x \to \frac{\pi}{2}^{-}} u(x) = - \infty\).
Then,
\[
\int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{0} e^{-\tan x} \sec^{2}x \ \mathrm{d} x =
\int^{- \infty}_{0} e^{u} (- \mathrm{d} u) =
\int^{0}_{- \infty} e^{u} \ \mathrm{d} u =
\biggr [ e^{u} \biggr ]^{0}_{- \infty} = 1
\]
For indefinite integrals, one should cast the result in terms of the “original variables” only.
In the example above, the variable \(u = −\tan x\) led to \(u = - \tan \cfrac{\pi}{2}\) in one limit of integration. This was interpreted as \(\tan \cfrac{\pi}{2}^{-}\), but not \(\tan \cfrac{\pi}{2}^{+}\). In trigonometric functions, there are principal parts, which are:







Function
Principal part




\(\sin x\)
\(- \cfrac{\pi}{2} < x < \cfrac{\pi}{2}\)


\(\cos x\)
\(0 < x < \pi\)


\(\tan x\)
\(- \cfrac{\pi}{2} < x < \cfrac{\pi}{2}\)



For instance, if one performs a integration by substitution in \(\displaystyle \int^{1}_{0} \sqrt{1 - x^{2}} \ \mathrm{d} x\) by introducing \(x(\theta) = \sin \theta\) (and \(\mathrm{d} x = \cos \theta \ \mathrm{d} \theta\)), the integration limits have to be replaced by
\[
\begin{cases}
x = 0 \quad \longrightarrow \quad \sin \theta = 0
\quad \longrightarrow \quad \theta = 0 \ (\underline{\text{not}} \ \theta = \pm \pi, \pm 2 \pi, et \ cætera) \\
x = 1 \quad \longrightarrow \quad \sin \theta = 0
\quad \longrightarrow \quad  \theta = \cfrac{\pi}{2} \ (\underline{\text{not}} \ \theta = \cfrac{5 \pi}{2}, - \cfrac{3 \pi}{2}, et \ cætera)
\end{cases}
\]
In other words, the new variable \(\theta\), associated with the angle of a trigonometric function, should lie in the principal part. Then, one has
\[
\int^{1}_{0} \sqrt{1 - x^{2}} \ \mathrm{d} x =
\int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{0} \sqrt{1 - \sin^{2} \theta} \ \cos \theta \ \mathrm{d} \theta =
\int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{0} |\cos \theta| \ \cos \theta \ \mathrm{d} \theta
\]
Since \(\cos \theta \geq 0\) in the interval \(\left [ 0, \cfrac{\pi}{2} \right ]\), it follows that \(| \cos \theta | = \cos \theta\), which leads to
\[
\int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{0} |\cos \theta| \ \cos \theta \ \mathrm{d} \theta =
\int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{0} \cos^{2} \theta \ \mathrm{d} \theta
\]
This integral is performed by first noting that
\[
\cos (2x) = \cos^{2} x - \sin^{2} x = \cos^{2} x - (1 - \cos^{2} x) = 2 \cos^{2} x  - 1
\]
From which one has
\[
\cos^{2} x = \cfrac{1 + \cos (2x)}{2}
\]
Then,
\[
\int \cos^{2} x \ \mathrm{d} x =
\int \left [ \cfrac{1 + \cos (2x)}{2} \right ] \ \mathrm{d} x =
\cfrac{1}{2} \int 1 \ \mathrm{d} x + \cfrac{1}{2} \int \cos (2x) \ \mathrm{d} x =
\tag{2.1}
\]
\[
= \cfrac{x}{2} + \cfrac{\sin (2x)}{4} + c \quad (c \in \mathbb{R})
\tag{2.2}
\]
where a simple integration by substitution was invoked in the last passage.
The integral \(\displaystyle \int \sin^{2} x \ \mathrm{d} x\) is performed \(mutatis \ mutandis\).
A simple application of this result is the evaluation of the area \(S_{\circ}\) of a circle. Without loss of generality, consider a circle of radius \(r\) where the center is located at the origin \((0, 0)\) in cartesian coordinates \((x, y)\); this circle is described by \(x^{2} + y^{2} = r^{2}\), with \(-r \leq x\), \(y \leq r\). Since it is not a function, one should separate the curve conveniently in the upper semi-circle, described by \(y = \sqrt{r^{2} - x^{2}}\), and the lower semi-circle, given by \(y = - \sqrt{r^{2} - x^{2}}\). By symmetry argument, the area can be evaluated by the double of the area of the upper (or lower) semi-circle, which is
\[
S_{\circ} = 2 \int^{r}_{-r} \biggr [ \sqrt{r^{2} - x^{2}} - 0 \biggr ] \ \mathrm{d} x
\]
If one chooses the lower semi-circle, the integral should be the same,
\[
\int^{r}_{-r} \biggr [ 0 - \left ( - \sqrt{r^{2} - x^{2}} \right ) \biggr ] \ \mathrm{d} x =
\int^{r}_{-r} \sqrt{r^{2} - x^{2}} \ \mathrm{d} x
\]
Introducing the variable \(\theta\) through \(x = r \sin \theta\) (which implies \(\mathrm{d} x = r \cos \theta \ \mathrm{d} \theta\), one has
\[
S_{\circ} =
2 \int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{- \cfrac{\pi}{2}} \sqrt{r^{2} - r^{2} \sin^{2} \theta} \ (r \cos \theta) \ \mathrm{d} \theta =
2 r \int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{- \cfrac{\pi}{2}} \sqrt{r^{2} (1 - \sin^{2} \theta)} \ \cos \theta \ \mathrm{d} \theta
\]
Remember that
\[
\sin^{2} \theta + \cos^{2} \theta = 1
\quad \text{hence} \quad
\cos^{2} \theta = 1 - \sin^{2} \theta
\]
Then
\[
S_{\circ} =
2 r \int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{- \cfrac{\pi}{2}} \sqrt{r^{2} \cos^{2} \theta} \ \cos \theta \ \mathrm{d} \theta =
2 r^{2} \int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{- \cfrac{\pi}{2}} |\cos \theta| \cos \theta \ \mathrm{d} \theta
\]
Note that \(x = - r\) and \(x = r\) correspond to \(\theta = - \cfrac{\pi}{2}\) and \(\theta = \cfrac{\pi}{2}\), respectively. Since \(\cos \theta \geq 0\) when \(\theta \in \left [ - \cfrac{\pi}{2}, \cfrac{\pi}{2} \right ]\), then \(|\cos \theta| = \cos \theta\); hence,
\[
S_{\circ} = 2 r^{2} \int^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{- \cfrac{\pi}{2}} \cos^{2} \theta \ \mathrm{d} \theta
\]
Using \((2)\), this result leads to
\[
S_{\circ} = 2 r^{2} \left[ \cfrac{\theta}{2} + \cfrac{\sin (2 \theta)}{4} \right ]^{\cfrac{\pi}{2}}_{- \cfrac{\pi}{2}} = \pi r^{2}
\]
which is the area of a circle of radius \(r\).

14.5 Example of integration by parts

Reference: Hase (2022)

Consider the integral
\[
\int \ln x \ \mathrm{d} x
\]
One should notice in this case that the integrand is
\[
1 \cdot \ln x: \int \ln x \ \mathrm{d} x = \int 1 \cdot \ln x \ \mathrm{d} x
\]
Defining
\[
\begin{cases}
f(x) \ = \ln x \\
g'(x) = 1
\end{cases}
\quad \text{, then} \quad
\begin{cases}
f'(x) = \cfrac{1}{x} \\
g(x) \ = x
\end{cases}
\]
Therefore,
\[
\int \overbrace{\ln x}^{f} \cdot \overbrace{1}^{g'} \ \mathrm{d} x =
[ \ \overbrace{\ln x}^{f} \overbrace{x}^{g} \ ] - \int \overbrace{\cfrac{1}{x}}^{f'} \overbrace{x}^{g} \ \mathrm{d} x =
x \ln x - x + c \quad (c \in \mathbb{R})
\]
